channel.title: Stories from miamiherald.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best miamiherald.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: Florida Sees Most New Coronavirus Cases Reported After Three-Day Drop In Numbers
item.description: Florida had 1,413 new reported cases of COVID-19 Friday, the highest number of new cases since the outbreak began more than a month ago, according to the state's Department of Health. It also reported 58 new deaths since Thursday evening.
item.kicker: AND NOW THEY'RE OPENING THE BEACHES

item.title: Does Blood Type Matter When It Comes To Coronavirus? A Chinese Study Says Yes
item.description: People with type A blood are more likely to catch coronavirus and die from it, according to a new study published in Wuhan, China.

item.title: How A Mar-a-Lago Member Helped Set Up The Brazil Summit That Exposed Trump To Coronavirus
item.description: A member of President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago club delivered a letter requesting a summit with Brazil's Jair Bolsonaro. The meeting ended up inadvertently exposing Trump and others to the coronavirus.

item.title: Andrew Gillum Found In Miami Beach Hotel Room With Suspected Drugs, Police Report Says
item.description: Andrew Gillum, who in 2018 came within 34,000 votes of becoming Florida's governor, was discovered by police at a South Beach hotel early Friday morning in a room with bags of possible methamphetamine and in the company of a man who appeared to have overdosed on drugs, according to a Miami Beach police report.
item.kicker: 'I APOLOGIZE TO THE PEOPLE OF FLORIDA'

item.title: Powerful Caribbean Earthquake Shakes Buildings In Jamaica, Cuba — Even Downtown Miami
item.description: A powerful magnitude 7.7 earthquake struck 86 miles northwest of Jamaica on Tuesday afternoon, sending seismic energy that could be felt throughout the Caribbean and as far as coastal Florida.

item.title: Sexual Abuse At Florida Prison Was Systemic, Brazen, Lawsuit Says
item.description: A lawsuit says that a federal prison work camp employed no fewer than seven officers who took advantage of their access and authority to sexually abuse the women in their control.

item.title: Epstein's Death Inconsistent With Suicide, Expert Says
item.description: The circumstances surrounding Epstein's death were unusual: "He had been dead for three hours and didn't photograph how the body was found."

item.title: What's Affecting Some Florida Panthers' Ability To Walk? It's A Mystery
item.description: Something is affecting the walking ability of some Florida panthers and bobcats, and state scientists want the public's help documenting the mystery disorder.

item.title: How a future Trump Cabinet member gave a serial sex abuser the deal of a lifetime
item.description: How a future Trump Cabinet member gave a serial sex abuser the deal of a lifetime.

item.title: Fake Sultan Was Scamming A Miami Billionaire. Then He Ate Pork
item.description: A Saudi "sultan" tried to con Jeffrey Soffer, the super-rich real estate developer behind Turnberry Associates, owner of the Fontainebleau resort hotel and Aventura Mall in South Florida.

item.title: Miami-Dade wants to build apartments at schools for teachers
item.description: Amid a wide gap between modest teacher salaries and Miami's high housing prices, the county has a new plan: build apartments on school property and let faculty live there.
item.kicker: WOULD MAKE FOR AN EASY COMMUTE

item.title: Student says Spirit Air told her to flush hamster down toilet
item.description: A Miami Beach student says Spirit Airlines twice told her she could fly with her hamster, a certified emotional-support animal, but refused to allow the tiny pet on the plane at the airport.

item.title: Fight Club: Dark secrets of Florida's juvenile justice system
item.description: Documents, interviews and surveillance videos show a disturbing pattern of beatings doled out or ordered by underpaid officers, hundreds of them prison system rejects.

item.title: Destruction at dawn: What Hurricane Andrew did to South Florida 25 years ago
item.description: As the risk of a major hit from Hurricane Irma grows, a look back at what happened when Hurricane Andrew struck in 1992.

item.title: Secret meeting at Mar-a-Lago raises questions about Colombia peace and Trump
item.description: After five years of negotiations and five decades of combat with FARC, the country's current administration has reached a peace deal, but it requires US cooperation and funding. The former presidents who Trump met with, who were reportedly connected to Trump by Marco Rubio, have both been vocal about not supporting the peace process because it has required working with a terrorist group.

item.title: Jeb Bush And Derek Jeter Teaming Up In Pursuit Of Miami Marlins
item.description: Jeb Bush and Derek Jeter have joined forces in their bid to buy the Miami Marlins, according to sources familiar with the talks.

item.title: Undercooled meat. Dangerous fish. Health inspectors ding Trump's Mar-a-Lago kitchen
item.description: Inspectors found 13 violations at Donald Trump's fancy Mar-a-Lago kitchen, according to recently published reports — a record for an institution that charges $200,000 in initiation fees

item.title: Ben Carson visits Miami housing development — and gets stuck in elevator
item.description: Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson's two-day visit to Miami — his third stop on a national listening tour — started with Carson, Miami-Dade County Public Housing Director Michael Liu

item.title: Zika virus: Local transmission taking place in Miami Beach, Florida
item.description: A new area of ongoing Zika transmission has been identified in Miami Beach, according to sources familiar with discussions that Florida health officials held with local public officials Thursday to alert them.

item.title: Zika virus: Gov. Rick Scott confirms virus nation's first cases locally transmitted by mosquitoes in Downtown Miami, Miami-Dade and Broward counties
item.description: Zika virus is actively being transmitted by local mosquitoes in a one-square-mile area just north of Downtown Miami, Florida Gov. Rick Scott said Friday morning in confirming that four cases of Zika infection in Miami-Dade and Broward counties were acquired locally.
item.kicker: NO INFECTED PEOPLE IN THE HOSPITAL

item.title: Bitcoin not money Miami judge rules in laundering case
item.description: In a case closely watched in financial and tech circles, the judge threw out the felony charges against website designer Michell Espinoza, who had been charged with illegally transmitting and laundering $1,500 worth of Bitcoins.

item.title: North Miami police officer shot caretaker of autistic man on ground
item.description: A new cellphone video shows Charles Kinsey — a caretaker who had gone to retrieve an autistic patient — lying on the ground with his hands up. Kinsey was shot in the leg by Miami police.

item.title: In Florida, officials ban term climate change
item.description: The state of Florida is the region most susceptible to the effects of global warming in this country, according to scientists. Sea-level rise alone threatens 30 percent of the state's beaches over the next 85 years. But you would not know that by talking to officials at the Florida Department of Environmental Protection, the state agency on the front lines of studying and planning for these changes.
item.kicker: NOT JUST AN EVAPORATING RIVER IN EGYPT

item.title: Man rescued from Colorado department store's walls
item.description: Authorities say a man who was freed from a space between two walls of a Colorado department store may have been there for several days yelling for help.

item.title: Alex Rodriguez's DEA confession: Yes, I used steroids from fake Miami doctor
item.description: In a Drug Enforcement Administration conference room back in January, facing federal agents and prosecutors who granted him immunity, baseball's highest-paid player admitted everything.

item.title: Pope to bishops: Be creative about families' needs
item.description: Pope Francis has called for a creative, humble approach as the Vatican ponders why many in the Catholic Church have gone their own way on sexual and family issues like contraception, pre-marital sex and divorce.

item.title: McDonald's offers a 60-second lunch guarantee on weekdays
item.description: McDonald's is offering a new 60-second lunch guarantee at its drive-thrus. McDonald's guests at participating South Florida restaurants will receive timers when paying for their order in the drive-thru. The timers are then returned to the McDonald's crew member when their food is presented. This guarantee promises that customers will receive their meal within 60 […]

item.title: Dysfunctional Dolphins are the talk of the league
item.description: Jonathan Martin is headed to therapy and Richie Incognito has been suspended indefinitely after Incognito sent Martin a series of racially charged and threatening messages, including one in which Incognito called Martin, who is biracial, a "half-n—–."

item.title: Teen graffiti artist dies after Tasering by Miami Beach cops
item.description: At just 17, Israel Hernandez-Llach was already an award-winning artist, on the threshold of acclaim in Miami Beach art circles. He was a sculptor, painter, writer and photographer whose craft was inspired by his home country of Colombia and his adopted city, Miami. He was also a graffiti artist, known as "Reefa," who sprayed colorful […]

item.title: AP Exclusive: The CIA and a secret vacuum cleaner
item.description: Confined to the basement of a CIA secret prison in Romania about a decade ago, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, the admitted mastermind of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, asked his jailers whether he could embark on an unusual project: Would the spy agency allow Mohammed, who had earned his bachelor's in mechanical engineering, to design a vacuum cleaner?

item.title: Tracking the hunger strike
item.description: There are currently 105 prisoners on a hunger strike at Guantánamo Bay. 44 of those are being forcibly fed via feeding tubes. See how the strike has escalated over the past few months.

item.title: Opa-locka field was once the site of secret CIA base
item.description: An Opa-lock building served as the CIA base for an operation that overthrew a leftist Guatemalan president in the 1950s.

item.title: Fidel Castro suffered a stroke, Venezuelan doctor says – Cuba
item.description: Former Cuban leader Fidel Castro suffered a cerebral hemorrhage and his state of health is so precarious that he has trouble feeding, speaking and recognizing people, said a Venezuelan physician.

item.title: "Cocaine godmother" Griselda Blanco gunned down in Colombia
item.description: Griselda Bianco spent nearly two decades behind bars in the U.S. for drug trafficking and three murders before she was deported to Colombia in 2004.

item.title: Poland peels back layers on CIA detention center
item.description: On an idyllic lake surrounded by woods and a double row of mesh-and-razor-wire fences about 100 miles north of Warsaw, there stands a secluded villa that the CIA once used to interrogate — and allegedly torture —top al Qaida suspects.

item.title: 'Fresh Prince' replaces Harry Potter as entertainment for Guantánamo prisoners
item.description: Harry Potter books are passé among the prisoners. The adventures of the boy wizard have been supplanted by early episodes of Will Smith's 1990s TV comedy, "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," as a popular way to pass time among the 168 captives now in their second decade of U.S. detention.
item.kicker: 'JUMP ON IT' FUTURE GITMO DANCE CRAZE
